meta.title: Regional Ecological Summit 2026
meta.description: The Regional Ecological Summit 2026 was initiated by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev and aims to unite Central Asian countries to develop common solutions to combat climate change in partnership with the UN. This is not just a meeting - it is a two-year preparation process that started in 2024 and culminates in a high-level Summit in 2026, where agreed environmental initiatives and mechanisms for regional cooperation will be presented.

titles.slogan: Shared vision for a Resilient Future
titles.soon: Something interesting will be here soon

aboutSummit.title: <primary>The Regional Ecological Summit 2026</primary> is aimed at shaping a shared vision for the sustainable development of Central Asia.
aboutSummit.text1: The Summit aims to unite Central Asian countries in partnership with the UN to develop agreed solutions to climate and environmental challenges. This is a two-year process (2024–2026) that has received broad international and political support. The Summit's concept is based on the idea of "Bir Tamyr" ("Same Root") - a symbol of common heritage and collective action for a sustainable future of the region.
aboutSummit.text2: We live in an era when innovation and sustainable development are becoming the most important priorities. At our summit, you will be able to see how cutting-edge ideas and solutions can change the world for the better. We invite you to become part of this movement to build together a future that inspires and motivates.

programms.title: Program
programms.text: Every day at RES 2026 will bring inspiration, discoveries and opportunities for cooperation. Follow the most important moments and learn about unique events such as evening events, networking sessions and awards for the best innovative projects.

speakers.text: The best minds of our time will gather at RES 2026.
speakers.text1: We are proud to be able to present on our platform world leaders in technology, sustainable development and science. Our speakers are those who shape the future by making the most important decisions that change the world.

partners.title: Partners
partners.text: RES 2026 would not be possible without the support of our distinguished organizers, partners, and media partners.
partners.text1: These leading organizations play a key role in shaping this unique event and enable us to showcase the most advanced ideas.

connectionBanner.text: Join us at RES 2026 - a unique event that will become the center of innovation, technology and sustainable development!

footer.text: The summit will take place at the «Congress Center»

about.title: About the summit
about.presidentTextTitle: Quote by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan:
about.presidentText: «Many developing countries without access to the sea are facing water scarcity, glacier melt, desertification, and other extreme weather events. Addressing these challenges requires coordinated regional efforts and strong international support. At the same time, I believe that measures to combat climate change must remain balanced and inclusive, and respond to the legitimate development needs of countries. To strengthen our joint efforts in addressing climate change, I invite you to the Regional Ecological Summit, which will be held in Astana in partnership with the United Nations in April next year».
about.presidentInitiativeText:
"However, development cannot be sustainable without addressing the climate crisis. Central Asia is one of the regions most vulnerable to climate change on the planet. Warming here occurs twice as fast as the global average. In response, we are promoting a pragmatic and regionally coordinated climate agenda. Our commitments include participation in various international organizations and agreements. 

 In 2026, Kazakhstan, in partnership with the UN, will hold a Regional Ecological Summit, which is intended to become a platform for uniting Central Asian strategies and global ambitions".
about.presidentPosition: From the statement by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan, Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, at the Third United Nations Conference on Landlocked Developing Countries, Awaza, Turkmenistan, 2025
about.text2: The Regional Ecological Summit 2026, initiated by the President of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, aims to unite Central Asian countries in partnership with the UN to develop agreed solutions to climate and environmental challenges. This is a two-year process (2024–2026) that has received broad international and political support. The Summit's concept is based on the idea of "Bir Tamyr" ("Same Root") - a symbol of common heritage and collective action for a sustainable future of the region.
about.text3: The Regional Ecological Summit 2026, held in partnership with the United Nations and other international organizations, aims to bring together the countries of Central Asia to develop coordinated solutions on climate and environmental challenges. These include the preservation of the Aral Sea and addressing the shrinking of the Caspian Sea basin, the promotion of green financing and low-carbon technologies, as well as the development of joint initiatives, declarations, and an Action Programme for 2026–2030 to support the region’s sustainable development.
about.aboutText1: The Regional Ecological Summit 2026 was initiated by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev and aims to unite Central Asian countries to develop common solutions to combat climate change in partnership with the UN. This is not just a meeting - it is a two-year preparation process that started in 2024 and culminates in a high-level Summit in 2026, where agreed environmental initiatives and mechanisms for regional cooperation will be presented.
about.aboutText2: The United Nations expressed its support for the Summit through General Assembly Resolution 78/147 of 19 December 2023, entitled “Central Asia facing environmental challenges: strengthening regional solidarity for sustainable development and prosperity.”
about.aboutText3: The initiative was further enshrined in a number of key political documents adopted at the level of Heads of State in 2024, including:
about.aboutText31: the Karabakh Declaration of the Informal Summit of the Organization of Turkic States (6 July 2024, Azerbaijan);
about.aboutText32: the Joint Statement of the Sixth Consultative Meeting of the Heads of State of Central Asia (9 August 2024, Kazakhstan);
about.aboutText33: the Bishkek Declaration of the 21st Summit of the Organization of Turkic States (6 November 2024, Kyrgyz Republic).
about.aboutText34:
In 2025, the initiative gained further international recognition during the opening ceremony of the UN Regional Centre for the Sustainable Development Goals for Central Asia and Afghanistan in Almaty, Kazakhstan, attended by UN Secretary-General António Guterres, as well as at the Third United Nations Conference on Landlocked Developing Countries held in Awaza, Turkmenistan. 

 RES 2026 aims to bring together the countries of Central Asia, in partnership with the United Nations and other international organizations, to develop common solutions to combat climate change and address broader environmental challenges. Particular emphasis will be placed on identifying the region’s concrete needs for green financing to support adaptation measures, advance low-carbon technologies, and strengthen environmental resilience across Central Asia. The Summit will serve as a regional platform for dialogue and solidarity, enhancing cooperation among governments, international organizations, scientific institutions, and the business community. It will also contribute to raising awareness of priority environmental issues, identifying practical solutions, and shaping joint action plans for the future in support of the region’s sustainable development.
about.aboutText4:
"However, development cannot be sustainable without addressing the climate crisis. Central Asia is one of the regions most vulnerable to climate change on the planet. Warming here occurs twice as fast as the global average. In response, we are promoting a pragmatic and regionally coordinated climate agenda. Our commitments include participation in various international organizations and agreements. 

 In 2026, Kazakhstan, in partnership with the UN, will hold a Regional Ecological Summit, which is intended to become a platform for uniting Central Asian strategies and global ambitions".
about.aboutText5:
The Regional Ecological Summit 2026 in partnership with the UN is a platform for uniting Central Asian countries in developing agreed working solutions and mechanisms that reflect a regional approach to overcoming climate and environmental challenges, including the tragedy of the Aral Sea, which has become a global symbol of environmental degradation, and the steady decline in the level of the Caspian Sea. Special attention will be paid to the formation of real needs of Central Asia in 'green' financing aimed at supporting adaptation measures, developing low-carbon technologies and strengthening the environmental sustainability of the region. 

 The Summit creates a regional platform for dialogue and solidarity, strengthening cooperation between states, international organizations, scientific and business communities. It contributes to raising awareness of priority environmental issues, finding practical solutions and forming joint action plans for the future aimed at sustainable development of the region. The goal is to form specific initiatives and mechanisms for joint action. Adoption of the Joint Declaration of Heads of State of Central Asia on regional cooperation in ecology and sustainable development. 

 Approval of the Regional Action Program with UN agencies (2026–2030) for a sustainable future of Central Asia, including regional initiatives on thematic areas of the Summit, launch of new environmental projects and initiatives in the directions of the Summit. Preparation for the summit began in 2024 and includes a series of regional consultations. The Summit will be the culmination of this process and will give political impetus to the environmental agenda of the region. The initiative strengthens the existing efforts of countries, complementing them with a regional dimension. The basis will be a coordinated environmental agenda, including updated climate goals of Central Asian countries.
about.resText1:
The Regional Ecological Summit 2026 (RES 2026) was initiated by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan, Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, during the 78th session of the UN General Assembly in September 2023. 
 At the Astana International Forum in May 2025, it was announced that the Summit’s agenda would be expanded from a climate-focused framework to a broader environmental scope.
about.resText2:
The initiative is reflected in the concept of «Bir Tamyr» (Same Root). The word «Tamyr» exists in almost all languages of the region and carries a profound meaning: roots as a symbol of common history and connection to nature, veins as the symbol of pulse and movement within the region, the intertwining of vessels, spirit, and culture. It is a metaphor for connection, resilience, and shared heritage that unites Central Asia not by political borders, but by meaning, memory, and future. 

 The visual representation of the countries of Central Asia is reflected in the Summit emblem (logo): different in shape, color, and character, yet standing together as a symbol of unity in diversity. The reference to the barcode shape also symbolizes a common space for dialogue and action, modern approaches, innovations, and the technological nature of solutions. 

 The Summit reflects this image: one region – shared challenges – collective action. It will bring together governments, international organizations, the scientific community, business, civil society, and youth to lay the foundation for a shared, environmentally sustainable future.
about.resText3: Preparations for the Summit commenced in 2024 and include a series of regional consultations.

kazakhstan.title: About Kazakhstan
kazakhstan.text1:
Kazakhstan is the largest country in the world that does not have direct access to the World Ocean. Most of the country's territory is made up of deserts – 44% and semi-deserts-14%. Steppes occupy 26% of the area of Kazakhstan, forests-5.5%. There are 8,5 thousand rivers in the country. 

 The north-eastern part of the Caspian Sea is part of the republic. The Aral Sea is divided between Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan. There are 48 thousand large and small lakes in Kazakhstan. The largest of them are Balkhash, Zaisan and Alakol. The distance from the oceans determines the sharply continental climate of the country. 

 The administrative and territorial structure of the country includes
kazakhstan.climateText: The weather of Kazakhstan is sharply continental, with large temperature fluctuations between summer and winter, dry air and low precipitation. All four seasons are pronounced here: cold winters, hot dry summers, short and changeable spring, and warm autumn. In the north, winters are harsher (temperatures can drop to -45 °C) and summers are warmer; in the south, winters are milder (near zero) and summers are hotter, with daytime temperatures up to +40°C and above.

etc.strategicVisionIntro: Kazakhstan has adopted the following Strategic Documents:

strategicDocuments.0: Strategy for achieving Carbon Neutrality until 2060
strategicDocuments.1: IT AIMS to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 17% from 1990 levels by 2035
strategicDocuments.2: Concepts for the transition of the Republic of Kazakhstan to a «green economy»
strategicDocuments.3: The concept of managing all types of waste for 2026-2030
strategicDocuments.4: The concept of conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity will cover the period from 2025 to 2035

nationalInitiativesIntro.text1: Support for investment projects financed through utilization fee revenues.
nationalInitiativesIntro.text2: Incentive payments to support waste collection, sorting, and recycling.
nationalInitiativesIntro.text3: the first in Central Asia, providing for the introduction of digital tracking of all waste streams and the establishment of a National Waste Management Operator.

nationalInitiatives.text1: is a large-scale national environmental campaign under the auspices of the Presidentof the Republic of Kazakhstan K. Tokayev, aimed at creating an ecological culture through cleaning territories (settlements, natural objects, banks of reservoirs), planting trees (millions of seedlings) and combating unauthorized landfills, involving young people, business and government agencies, with a focus on waste management, innovation and landscaping.
nationalInitiatives.text2: is an initiative in Kazakhstan, with the aim of creating woodlands until 2025, and then extended until 2027. The goal is to plant and sow $ 2 billion. saplings of tree and shrub species, including saxaul, pine, birch and others, in the state forest fund to restore forests and improve the ecological situation.
nationalInitiatives.title3: The International Fund for Biodiversity Conservation
nationalInitiatives.text3: is an initiative of Kazakhstan that will unite the efforts of states, international organizations (UNDP, UNESCO, FAO) and NGOs to finance the protection of ecosystems, develop ecotourism, introduce eco-technologies and raise awareness, working according to the best international standards for sustainable development and conservation of flora and fauna.
nationalInitiatives.title4: UN Regional Center for Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) for Central Asia and Afghanistan
nationalInitiatives.text4: The <bold>UN Regional Center for Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) for Central Asia and Afghanistan has been established in Kazakhstan (Almaty).</bold> It was approved by the UN member states in March 2025, opened in August 2025, and its goal is to contribute to the achievement of 17 global SDGs by 2030.

preparationProcess.title: Preparatory process
preparationProcess.subtitle: The Summit was preceded by a two-year preparatory process focused on shaping its substantive agenda and expanding the network of partners.
preparationProcess.text: In 2025 alone, eleven major regional and international consultations were held at key environmental fora, including the 62nd sessions of the Subsidiary Body for Scientific and Technological Advice and the Subsidiary Body for Implementation (SB 62) of the UNFCCC in Bonn, Germany; the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York, USA; COP30 in Belém, Brazil; and the seventh session of the United Nations Environment Assembly (UNEA-7) in Nairobi, Kenya.

astana.title: Astana
astana.subtitle: The capital of the Republic of Kazakhstan, a dynamic metropolis where nomadic cultural traditions combine with innovation and world-class architecture
astana.historyText:
The history of Astana begins in 1830 with the construction of the Akmola fortress on the Ishim River. A city grew around it - an important trade and economic center of the region. 

 During the Soviet period, the city was named Tselinograd and became one of the key centers for the development of virgin lands. It was then that it actively developed as an industrial, educational and scientific city, laying the foundation for future growth. 

 In 1997, a historic decision was made to move the capital of Kazakhstan from Almaty to Akmola. Already in 1998, the city received a new name - Astana - and a new status, becoming a symbol of independence, renewal and strategic development of the country. 

 On May 6, 1998, Akmola was renamed Astana, and in 1999 it received the title of "City of Peace" by UNESCO decision. Since 2000, the city has been a member of the International Assembly of Capitals and Major Cities.

histories.text3: Transfer of the capital from Almaty

cultureAndTraditions.title: Culture and traditions
cultureAndTraditions.text1:
Astana is a city where cultural heritage is carefully preserved while creating a modern identity. Here, the national traditions of Kazakhstan are organically woven into the rhythm of the dynamic capital, forming a unique atmosphere of openness, respect and diversity. 

 The cultural life of the city is based on the traditions of the nomadic people: respect for elders, hospitality, unity with nature and reverence for family. These values are felt not only in holidays and rituals, but also in the daily life of the city - in the warm attitude towards guests, the desire for dialogue and mutual understanding.
cultureAndTraditions.text2:
National holidays occupy a special place in the life of Astana. Nauryz, Capital Day, Independence Day are celebrated on a grand scale and brightly, uniting residents and guests of the city. Squares and parks are filled with concerts, fairs, national games and theatrical performances. 

 The cultural space of the capital is rich and diverse. Theaters, museums, galleries and concert halls coexist with modern art spaces, street culture festivals and international exhibitions. Astana has become a platform for dialogue between different cultures, where traditional art and modern forms of self-expression meet.

venue.title: Event venue
venue.subtitle: Modern space for international dialogue and innovation

aboutSquare.title: About the venue
aboutSquare.text1: The venue is conveniently located, easily accessible from the airport and city center, and fully ready to receive participants, speakers and guests from different countries.
aboutSquare.text2: RES2026 will take place at a modern congress and exhibition venue in Astana, meeting international standards for business and scientific events. Spacious halls, flexible layout and high-tech equipment create comfortable conditions for plenary sessions, sectional meetings and exhibition areas.

baiterek.title: Baiterek Monument
baiterek.subtitle:
One of the main symbols of Astana and modern Kazakhstan history. 
 It was opened in 2002 and embodies the idea of revival, growth and aspiration for the future.
baiterek.aboutMonumentText:
The height of the monument is 97 meters, symbolizing 1997 - the year of the transfer of the capital of Kazakhstan to Astana. The structure is a tall tower topped with a golden glass sphere. Inside the sphere is an observation deck offering a panoramic view of the city. 

 The image of «Baiterek» is based on the ancient Turkic myth of the Tree of Life, at the top of which the bird Samruk lays a golden egg - a symbol of the sun, life and prosperity. This legend reflects the connection between past, present and future. 

 Today «Baiterek» is a popular tourist attraction and cultural symbol of the capital, attracting guests with its architecture and deep symbolic meaning.
baiterek.insideMonumentSubtitle: The interior space of the «Baiterek» monument is open to visitors and consists of several levels.
baiterek.insideMonumentText:
The lower part of the monument houses an entrance hall with ticket offices, a souvenir shop and an information area for guests. Exhibition materials telling about the history of the creation of «Baiterek» and the development of the capital are also located here. 

 Access to the upper levels is via a high-speed elevator. During the ascent, visitors can see elements of the tower's internal structure. 

 On the upper level, inside the glass sphere, there is an observation deck. From here, a circular panoramic view of Astana and its main architectural objects opens up. In the center of the hall is the composition «Ayaly Alakan» - the palm print of the First President of the Republic of Kazakhstan, symbolizing peace, harmony and unity. 

 Interactive and multimedia elements are also located inside the sphere, allowing you to learn more about the symbolism of the monument and the history of the city. 

 Visiting «Baiterek» gives you the opportunity not only to see the city from above, but also to get to know the cultural and symbolic meaning of one of the main monuments of Astana in more depth.

visa.title: Visa
visa.infoText1: Foreign citizens may need a visa to enter the Republic of Kazakhstan depending on their citizenship and purpose of travel. Before submitting documents, it is recommended to check if a visa-free regime applies to your country.
visa.infoText21: Through the consulate or embassy of Kazakhstan in your country of residence
visa.infoText22: Electronic visa (eVisa) - available for citizens of some countries through the official portal
visa.infoText23: Upon invitation from an individual or legal entity in Kazakhstan (for business, work and private visas)
visa.infoText3: Before traveling, be sure to check the current visa requirements at the consulate of the Republic of Kazakhstan or on official government resources.
visa.visaFreeText: Citizens of more than 70 countries, including European Union states, the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada, South Korea, Japan, the UAE and others, can enter Kazakhstan without a visa for up to 30 days. For citizens of EAEU countries (Russia, Belarus, Kyrgyzstan, Armenia), a stay of up to 90 days is allowed.
visa.visaJoinText1: Citizens of countries not on the visa-free list require a visa issued at consulates or embassies of Kazakhstan.
visa.visaJoinText2: To obtain it, you need an invitation from the host party (travel agency, hotel, individual or organization) and a completed online application through the Visa.mfa.kz portal.
visa.eVisaText1: Travelers from a number of countries can apply for an electronic visa without visiting a consulate.
visa.eVisaText2:
eVisa is available for entry through international airports of Kazakhstan, including Nur-Sultan Nazarbayev Airport. It is enough to submit an application online, pay the fee and receive the visa by email. 
 You can find additional information on the website - Visa

weather.title: Weather
weather.springText: Spring comes late and uncertainly in Astana. In March, frosts and snow are still possible, and the weather often changes during the day. April brings snowmelt and strong winds. Real warmth is felt closer to the end of May, when the temperature rises to a comfortable +15…+22 °C.
weather.springMinusText: winter still holds, frosts are possible
weather.summerText: Summer is hot and dry. Daytime temperatures often reach +30…+35 °C, but thanks to low humidity, the heat is easier to bear. Evenings become cooler. Precipitation is rare, sometimes thunderstorms with strong winds occur. The best time for walks and outdoor events.
weather.autumnText: Autumn is short and cool. In September it is still warm and sunny, but already in October the weather changes dramatically: the wind intensifies, rains come, and the first frosts appear. In November, snow often falls, and the city gradually prepares for winter.
weather.winterText: Winter is long, cold and windy. Temperatures often drop to −25…−35 °C, and on some days it can be even lower. Strong winds intensify the feeling of cold. Despite the frosts, winter is often sunny, with clear skies.
